text: let's see if we can get us going it
started at a fast-food drive-through in
Gloucester or the new year's resolution
I also pay for the person behind me is
that okay
buying dinner for strangers in the queue
was Luke Cameron's first random act of
kindness
since then the 26 year old has performed
a good deed daily keeping a diary online
from donating his personal possessions
to a charity shop and cooking a meal for
elderly neighbors to giving a
Valentine's rose to someone who'd been
jilted I've opened doors for people I
ladies filled of stuff on the floor from
a handbag I hope to pick it up he vowed
to make strangers smile every day this
year how good as this made you feel oh I
feel amazing because of it you know it
to be selfless is actually much nicer
than being selfish instead of thinking
about yourself all the time and what you
can gain it's about actually as you know
what I've helped that person you walk
away and go you know what they're having
a better day than I am maybe and that's
a good thing
Luke's good deeds have been viewed by
thousands on the Internet what cottage
cheese homages here he is handing out
the food to the homeless water and
giving away his gamers console a young
deserving person but despite all the
YouTube hits and global media coverage
Luke says this isn't about achieving
fame but about getting others to be kind
I didn't go into this with any agenda I
didn't go into this wanting anything out
of it I'm overwhelmed by the amount of
media attention that has happened around
my blog I want to inspire people that's
the only reason I'm doing
so good deed 110 ticked off the list
255 more to go till the end of the year
John Kay BBC News Cheltenham
